Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Frequency-Translational Quadrature-Hybrid Transceivers for Small-Cell Wireless Infrastructure
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this project is to enable flexible carrier aggregation in mobile wireless networks using frequency-translational quadrature-hybrid (FTQH) technology. The customer demand for wireless connectivity keeps increasing both in terms of more connected devices and higher data rates. Carrier aggregation is a critical technology to further increase data rates for next-generation heterogeneous wireless networks. It lets mobile network operators and neutral hosts make more effective use of their fragmented spectral resources. Mobile communications are now an essential part of our personal and professional lives and impact all aspects of our society from business, to government, to education and the non-profit sector. The small business concern will generate OEM RF front-end products for the small-cell base station market which is growing rapidly with more than 10 million small-cell base station shipments estimated in 2020. This will strengthen the US commercial technology base and generate US employment opportunities as it grows its workforce.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project will demonstrate the technical and commercial feasibility of the FTQH technology. This technology promises to enable the design of modular, flexible RF front ends for small-cell base stations. FTQH is a novel architectural approach that leverages existing RF filtering, RF switching and RF routing technologies while enabling low cost, high performance, modular RF front ends for flexible carrier aggregation.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The demand for wireless data traffic keeps growing rapidly. Emerging applications such as live video streaming, virtual reality, and cloud computing all need high-speed and reliable data access. The wireless network service providers are developing the next-generation (5G) wireless network to address these challenges. The higher data throughput can be achieved through spectrum aggregation and network densification in the wireless infrastructure. Due to regulation and legacy issues, the existing wireless spectrum is highly fragmented.  Communicating concurrently across these non-contiguous spectrums imposes huge technology challenge in the RF front end design. The complexity of the circuits grows rapidly as the number of possible frequency band combinations increases and flexible spectrum aggregation becomes a critical technology.
Concurrent Wireless is committed to addressing these challenges for the next-generation wireless networks. With the support of this SBIR Phase-I project, we developed and validated a family of technology named Frequency Translational Quadrature Hybrid (FTQH). The FTQH circuits can greatly reduce the RF front end design complexity in the 5G wireless base stations. The flexible filter aggregation (FFA) feature can interface the existing dedicated RF filters for each frequency band to a pair of wideband antennas. This leads to highly flexible RF front end designs that ease the development and deployment of wireless small cell base stations.
The Research and development of this SBIR Phase-I covers extensive simulation of the FTQH technology, physical prototypes and measurements to validate the technology, and exploration of suitable and practical product forms of the FTQH technology integration into small cell base stations. We also explored other possible applications of the FTQH technology beyond wireless small cells. Other wireless communication equipment such as distributed antenna systems, public safety systems, and concurrent spectrum monitors are candidate applications that face similar technology challenges and can be addressed with the FTQH technologies.
The FTQH technology developed at Concurrent Wireless can help to better utilize the spectrum for the next generation wireless technology and can make an impact on the society as a whole. We believe wireless technology has been and will continue to be a key cornerstone of our life, society, and culture.
